Here, we explore the outcomes of severe climate changes on urbanized marsh areas during key periods of water stress in the Fertile Crescent through the prism of ancient Tel Dan. Climate models are now projecting widespread aridity across the Mediterranean Basin over the coming century (
28 ,
29 ). This predicted growth in aridity will potentially impose exceptional stress on already limited water resources (
30 ,
31 ) with substantial impacts on the environment, on society (
32 ), and on human health (
33 ,
34 ). The outcomes of severe drought events in the past may resonate with present declines in precipitation (
1 ) in the drylands of the Middle East and prefigure their aftermaths.
